goal.tools.mc.program.goal.prolog.trans

Class PrologDerives

  • java.lang.Object
    • goal.tools.mc.program.goal.prolog.trans.PrologDerives
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Derives<PrologAtom>

    public class PrologDerives
extends java.lang.Object
implements Derives<PrologAtom>
    Implements the methods for determining whether a mental state condition can become (un)derivable after certain updates to the mental state when the Prolog KRT is used. Works only for a restricted number of Prolog operators and predicates: conjunction, negation, and arithmetic.
    Author:
    sungshik

    • Method Detail

      • mscderneg

        public boolean mscderneg(MentalStateCondition msc,
                TauUpdate<PrologAtom> update)
        Description copied from interface: Derives
        Determines whether the specified mental state condition can become underivable from the mental state if the specified updates are brought about. Implementations of this method probably over-approximate in the sense that if the specified MSC can become underivable, then this method returns true. The converse is, however, not true: if this method returns true, then it is not necessarily the case that the specified MSC can really become underivable.
        Specified by:
        mscderneg in interface Derives<PrologAtom>
        Parameters:
        msc - - The mental state condition to check whether it can become underivable for.
        update - - The updates that are brought about to the mental state.
        Returns:
        true if the MSC can become underivable in an over- approximative fashion; false otherwise.

      • mscderpos

        public boolean mscderpos(MentalStateCondition msc,
                TauUpdate<PrologAtom> update)
        Description copied from interface: Derives
        Determines whether the specified mental state condition can become derivable from the mental state if the specified updates are brought about. Implementations of this method probably over-approximate in the sense that if the specified MSC can become derivable, then this method returns true. The converse is, however, not true: if this method returns true, then it is not necessarily the case that the specified MSC can really become derivable.
        Specified by:
        mscderpos in interface Derives<PrologAtom>
        Parameters:
        msc - - The mental state condition to check whether it can become derivable for.
        update - - The updates that are brought about to the mental state.
        Returns:
        true if the MSC can become derivable in an over- approximative fashion; false otherwise.

      • plderneg

        public boolean plderneg(LMHashSet<jpl.Atom> plus,
               LMHashSet<jpl.Atom> min,
               jpl.Term term,
               goal.tools.mc.program.goal.prolog.trans.PrologDerInfo info)
        Determines whether the specified term can become underivable from a set of Prolog clauses at least containing the knowledge rules rules, if the atoms in plus are added and the atoms in min deleted. This method is over-approximative in the sense that if the specified term can become underivable, true is returned. However, it may happen that if the specified does not become underivable, true is returned nevertheless.
        Parameters:
        plus - - The set of terms that are added.
        min - - The set of terms that are deleted.
        term - - The term to check for whether it can become underivable.
        info - - Information about the search so far; for instance, we need to check that the same knowledge rule is not applied twice, because this may result in non-terminating behavior.
        Returns:
        - true if the term can become underivable in an over- approximative fashion; false otherwise.

      • plderpos

        public boolean plderpos(LMHashSet<jpl.Atom> plus,
               LMHashSet<jpl.Atom> min,
               jpl.Term term,
               goal.tools.mc.program.goal.prolog.trans.PrologDerInfo info)
        Determines whether the specified term can become derivable from a set of Prolog clauses at least containing the knowledge rules rules, if the atoms in plus are added and the atoms in min deleted. This method is over-approximative in the sense that if the specified term can become derivable, true is returned. However, it may happen that if the specified does not become derivable, true is returned nevertheless.
        Parameters:
        plus - - The set of terms that are added.
        min - - The set of terms that are deleted.
        term - - The term to check for whether it can become derivable.
        info - - Information about the search so far; for instance, we need to check that the same knowledge rule is not applied twice, because this may result in non-terminating behavior.
        Returns:
        - true if the term can become derivable in an over- approximative fashion; false otherwise.
